item.title: We don't need quotas in tech
Do you remember del.icio.us?
item.description: Yep, this is old. Del.icio.us was a link-sharing / personal link storage system that existed wayyyy in the past. Before Chrome, Firefox, Safari or Edge had profiles and the ability to store your favorite pages and access them from different computers. Because that was the problem Delicious solved: accessing your favorite links from your work‚Äôs computer or at home. Back when that was cool. Today, reviewing my old accounts and changing passwords I bumped into it, and logged in just to see if it still works.

item.title: My standup Shell Script
item.description: At Teamwork‚Äôs Mobile Team we hold a Standup meeting every day, at 11:00 AM Irish Time. That‚Äôs Noon for me, here in Spain. And more than a Standup is a ‚ÄúStatus Update‚Äù to let other members of the Mobile sub-teams know roughly what I‚Äôm doing and if I have some errand to run, or won‚Äôt be available for several hours, etc. It’s also a good way to keep the connection with the rest of the team.

item.title: Reaching iCloud from the command line
item.description: Recently I‚Äôve abandoned Dropbox and switched over iCloud. I‚Äôll talk about the reasons in another post, but sounds crazy to me that right now iCloud is a better option than Dropbox in the Mac… I have different things stored in my Cloud Storage. Some repos from unfinished projects, living proof of that moment‚Äôs abandoned hype, some personal documents, all my iPad Apps docs, shared configuration for Bash / Zsh and lots of small scripts.

item.title: Writing again
item.description: This time in English! OK, I love to write. My old blog (in Spanish) is a testament to this. Lots of words were written there over many, many years. I also like to write fiction, but I‚Äôm so ashamed of everything I figure out that often I just compose things in my mind, where Facebook can‚Äôt read them (for now at least) Wanted to write again for a while now, but been agonizing (and procrastinating over) deciding the most stupid of things.

item.title: How To Recover A Deleted Git Stash
item.description: This is a scary story, not like a horror movie, but frightening enough to give any developer the shivers. The story goes a little something like this‚Ä¶ A customer directs your attention to a bug you know you‚Äôve solved, tested and shipped. You fixed it one day ago so the bug can‚Äôt be there, the customer must be wrong?! After running the application, waiting to not see the bug, it‚Äôs there again!

item.title: Not Good At Teamwork
item.description: Are you good at teamwork? Yes, of course Who would say something different at a job interview? This question, or something similar, almost always appears when you are talking with people you want to work with at a new company. It‚Äôs natural to ask, because almost every project is a team effort, with many people involved: designers, project managers, product owners, customers, users of the product, developers etc. They call it ‚Äústakeholders‚Äù meaning ‚Äúpeople interested in building something together‚Äù.

item.title: Maintain Your Sourcetree Bookmarks Throught Several Machines
item.description: If you use git, you probable have heard about SourceTree, the superb Atlassian git client, that solves 99% of your day-to-day git needs, connects to Github & Bitbucket repos and works on Mac and Windows. On top of that: it’s free, as in beer. Keep reading this post in the Mobile Jazz Blog

Hi there! I‚Äôm Diego, a Spanish Mobile Developer based in the warm sunny south of Spain. Seville is my home city and a beautiful place you should visit if haven‚Äôt done already. Ping me on twitter if you‚Äôre visiting and we can arrange some üçªif time permits. I‚Äôve been typing on keyboards since ‚Äò88, when my parents got me a nice cassette-loading, green-screen AMSTRAD CPC 464. Since then I‚Äôve been doing a lot of coding and just a few times I‚Äôve been proud of code punched by me.

Diego Freniche Brito - Mobile Apps Developer / Teacher Contact info Social: Twitter: https://twitter.com/dfreniche LinkedIn: http://es.linkedin.com/in/dfreniche Github: https://github.com/dfreniche StackOverflow: http://stackoverflow.com/users/225503/diego-freniche Blog: http://www.freniche.com Current location: ‚òÄÔ∏è El Saucejo, Seville (Spain) üåç Travelling sometimes Current Position (Jan 2018 - ) Mobile developer at Teamwork.com. Technologies used: Node.js, CoffeeScript, Axway Appcelerator, Swift, Java (for the native modules and extensions), gulp, bash, Ruby.
